titleStmt.title: An Encoding Model for Genetic Editions
titleStmt.author: Fotis Jannidis, Elena Pierazzo, Malte Rehbein

publicationStmt.authority: TEI MS SIG, Genetic Edition Workgroup

div.head: About this Document
div.p: This document contains the draft of an encoding model for Genetic Editions and Genetic Editing. The document is the product of a Workgroup on Genetic Editions (chair: Fotis Jannidis), which is part of the TEI MS SIG (chairs: Elena Pierazzo, Malte Rehbein, Amanda Galley).

The purpose of this workgroup is to try to elaborate an Application Profile able to encode genetic editions and, in general, genetic phenomena. The application profile will discuss how to use existing TEI elements in a genetic framework, presenting, where necessary, new elements and will take the form of a TEI extension.

With respect to the TEI P5 Guidelines, the present document aims to integrate Chapter 11. Representation of Primary Sources and Chapter 12. Critical Apparatus. It might be the case that it will, at the end of the process described in the following section, constitute a self standing new Guidelines chapter, but this decision will be taken later on.
The current state of this document reflects the discussion held in three different meetings:

list.item: MS SIG meeting held in London during the annual members’ TEI meeting (November 2008); the minutes of the meeting can be found here: .
Genetic Edition workgroup held in London (March 2009); minutes can be found here: .
Workshop "Genetic Editions in a Digital Framework", held in Paris, 14/15 May 2009, and following discussion; programme of the workshop can be found here:

div.p: The working group has made a large use of the HNML. HyperNietzsche Markup Language and following versions (GML Genetic Markup Language) written by Paolo D'Iorio and collaborators for the HyperNietzsche project. We would like to thank Paolo D'Iorio for his invaluable contribution in the early stages of the work.

div.head: Methodology
div.p: The stages we will follow to complete the present encoding model are the following:

list.item: Initially, we will work on a pseudo-encoding which is tightly bound to our own terminology [Stage completed on July 2009].
In a second step we will try to map this pseudo-encoding to the actual TEI encoding framework, in cooperation with Lou Burnard. The result will be presented at TEI' Members Meeting 2009.

The same step-by-step approach will be taken for the standardisation process:
First we develop an application profile, that is, a well-documented TEI customisation.
This will be presented to te TEI Council as a proposed modification of the TEI
If the TEI Council approves it, the Council will also decide how it should be integrated into the current Guidelines.

div.head: Conventions used
div.p: Although the entire document is a draft and therefore susceptible of changes, some sections are less stable than others. In particular, when a section or a particular element requires further discussion or is considered an open problem, such a section or element is marked by a * mark.
All newly introduced elements are marked by the namespace prefix ge:, while TEI elements are not marked by any namespace prefix.

div.head: Theoretical Framework
div.p: The genetic approach differentiates from a more traditional text study approach because it is not only interested on 'what is on the page', but also to reconstruct the process necessary to produce 'what is on the page'.

The encoding model will present how to handle Genetic Transcription (a transcription of a single document), how to reconstruct a Genetic Dossier, meaning how to describe genetic relations amongst multiple witnesses, and how to prepare a Genetic Edition based on a single or multiple witnesses. In this latter case the model can be used both in the case of a full transcription of all extant witnesses, and in the case of the full transcription of only one base-text, with the others witnesses reconstructable via collation.
The model aims to be independent of presuppositions made by any particular theoretical framework; therefore a couple of typical dichotomies in editorial theory have to be recognised and discussed.

div.head: Fact (or record) vs. Interpretation
div.p: In German editorial theory there is a well known opposition between what is there on the source document, the record (Befund), and the interpretation of this phenomenon (Deutung). This seems to imply that there is a way to talk about the record without any interpretation, but this is certainly not entirely correct, because everything we say about a text is based on interpretation (using a not very strict meaning of the word), in particular in the realm of genetic criticism.See also the TEI’s (implicit) position on this point: we define markup, or (synonymously) encoding, as any means of making explicit an interpretation of a text (TEI Guidelines: v. A Gentle Introduction to XML). See also reference to Robinson and Solopova 1993/1997: 21: Any primary textual source… has its own semiotic system within it.[…] The two semiotic system are materially distinct, in that text written by hand is not the same as the text on the computer screen. On the other hand this truism cannot conceal the fact that there is an obvious difference between the interpretation that some trace of ink is indeed a specific letter and the assumption that a change in a manuscript at the first line has been made at the same time as the change in the next line because it adjusts the text to the new rhyme word introduced by the first change. Therefore we propose to talk about differing levels of interpretation as we might not be able to clearly differentiate between “what’s there” (document/fact) and “how does it relate” (text/interpretation).

div.head: Document vs. Text
div.p: In any branch of Manuscript Studies (Editing, Codicology, Palaeography, Art History, History) the first level of enquiry is always the document, the physical support that lies in front of the scholar’s eyes.

To understand the text that is contained in the manuscript, a deep study of the manuscript itself is fundamental: the layout, the type of script, the type of writing support, the binding and many other aspects are able to tell us about when, where and why this particular text was composed. The text therefore represents the second level of enquiry, not the first. In the case of modern draft manuscripts scholars must give detailed consideration to the layout, the different stratifications of writing and the disposition of these in the physical space; all of these, together with the understanding of the text, are required to gain insight about the composition, time of revisions, and flow of the text. Furthermore, for some kind of texts we know that the kind of physical support used to record them not only influences but may actually determine the text itself. For instance, the content and the length of letters are often determined by the size and quantity of paper available to the writer.

TEI’s approach prioritise the text level. Of the two possible main hierarchies potentially available to someone transcribing a primary source (text and document), the TEI privileges the text (hence Text Encoding Initiative) and relegates physical, topographical layout to empty elements (pb/, lb/, cb/) or attributes (add place="", note place=""). The TEI does not say that documents are not relevant, but that they are less relevant than texts; to use a bibliographical metaphor, texts are substantial while documents are accidental.

For genetic editions the document level is indeed crucial as in many case it is the only way to reconstruct the process of writing and re-writing contained by a specific document. We therefore think that we should offer two possible encoding approach: Document and Text.
We should then clarify the way we will use the following words:

list.item: Document the physical object, the manuscript or other primary source
Text the content of the document, the words written in their logical (non physical) sequence
Facsimile a surrogate representation (non necessarily digital) of the document (a photograph, a microfilm, a digital image)
Document level transcription of the content of a document according to its physical layout
Text level transcription of the content of a document according to its logical, semantic meaning
Text stage a reconstructible and possible timed stage of evolution of a text, represented by a document or by a revision campaign within one or more documents.

div.head: Aspects of Genetic Editions
div.p: Modern genetic editions encode the genetic process within one manuscript and over the course of two or more manuscripts; in this latter case quite often they also offer a view of each of the manuscripts as a single self-contained object. This is because the manuscript view provides the material basis for the relationships established by the inter-manuscript relationship. Therefore we propose to differentiate between the following aspects of a genetic edition:

list.item: The topological description description of the layout of the text and the basis for a rendition of a text as a diplomatic transcription.
Alterations like additions, deletions, substitutions.
Grouping Revisions groups of changes at different locations of one document, used to create sets which express the editorial assumption that these changes have been undertaken in one stage.
Comparison (Collation) expresses the differences between texts as the result of a comparison between documents.
Genetic Grouping groups phenomena in more than one document, in order to describe editorial assumption that these phenomena are related in some way.

Genetic Relations describes the genetic relation between different parts of a text,As in the case where a document describes the ordering of parts of a text contained in another document. It is the case, for instance of Beckett's That Time where the speeches of A, B and C are obsessively first subdivided and subsequently shuffled and reshuffled by the means of sequences of letters and numbers contained in a number of documents. and/or across several documents, as a series of steps on a path.
Chronology, Date and Time the encoding of the chronology of the text or parts of it in absolute or relative time.
Documenting Editorial Decisions documents the arguments which are the basis for editorial decisions to encode the text in a specific way including ways to express uncertainty and alternatives.

div.head: The Document-based Transcription
div.p:
The document-based transcription includes 4 hierarchically organised levels:
Document
Writing Surface (page, double page, folium, etc.)
Zone
Line (or p or other block elements)
We propose to use introduce a new element, ge:document to encode a document-based transcription, as an alternative to text, and to use a modified version of surface and zone.

A ge:document contains a sequence of surface elements. The surface element has been added a type attribute which suggested values are page, leaf, and similar. The orientation of the writing surface is defined either by a set of cartesian coordinates (measured from the top left corner) or implicitly stated by width and height of the page recorded within msDesc (namely within dimension or measure within objectDesc).

The surface element contains a sequence of zones. zones can be nested and grouped, can overlap and have a sequence level (i.e belong to a text stage), expressed by the seq attribute. Their positioning with respect to the surface element is defined by cartesian coordinates, measured from the top left corner. The element carries an sOrientation attribute which describes (in degrees) the orientation that the surface has taken to enable the content (writing, images) in that zone, with respect to the normal orientation of the surface. Note that the mechanism aims to describes the process by which the content of a specific zone has been supplied (i.e. the author has physically rotate the writing surface) more that the orientation of the writing.

Zones are arbitrarily defined by the editors according to the layout of the writing surface and can make use of a standardised vocabulary (e.g. the top margin). Their content can be:
ge:line: a sequence of lines of text
a p or other block paragraph-like elements
a graphic/image

In the following we can easily detect two main areas of writing, the diary entry (black ink) and another (supposedly later) annotation in blue ink.
In order to add the annotation in the blue ink, the diary page has been rotated 90° clockwise by the author. The page can be transcribed as follows (transcription line by line):

zone.ge:line: Fed Birds in the park today.

div.p: Second option (textual transcription within a document-based transcription)

zone.p:
Fed Birds in the park today.
Might write an article about
the Thick-billed Warbler.

Samaria is a Greek
brand of water that
comes from the natural
springs of Stilos, in
Crete

div.p: A document-based transcription, which is done page-by-page and possibly line-by-line, is very likely to generate overlapping with all block level elements. We have therefore introduced a new class of elements called model.spanning which groups all elements that can be eventually spanned across pages and lines. All those elements have been provided with an spanTo attribute: when such an attribute is in use, the element must be empty. See the previous example encoded with spanned elements:

surface.zone:
1 April 2009
Fed Birds in the park today.
Might write an article about
the Thick-billed Warbler.

Samaria is a Greek
brand of water that
comes from the natural
springs of Stilos, in
Crete

div.head: *Alterations
div.p: Alterations occurs within a single manuscript, but it is an open question whether we can consider discrepancies amongst versions preserved by different manuscripts (dossier level) also as a sort of alteration. For instance, if by comparing (collating) two versions preserved by two witnesses we note a word has been added or deleted, should we encode it, within a collation, with add or del as we would when transcribing a single manuscript? Or do we need a completely new set of elements to do it? In a genetic process, at any point the author can decide to stop revising the text within a given document and decide to move to a new document (i.e. copy it anew), so the two phenomena (alterations at document level and alterations at dossier level) are indeed closely related. On the other hand we need to differentiate them because the one within a single document is explicitly marked by the author, while the one detected by comparison is only implicit. It may also happen that implicit alterations were perhaps marked in a lost intermediate version. This remains an open problem (see also).
The following discussion relates to the alterations at document level: for a discussion of their use at dossier level also see below.

div.head: Additions
div.p: Beside “normal” additions (see for instance the TEI definition of the add element: contains letters, words, or phrases inserted in the text by an author, scribe, annotator, or corrector.), we have outlined some other special kinds of additions, where text is added to the document but not to the text:

list.item:
Repetitions for which we have introduced a ge:repetition element. Repetitions can be of two main types:
Fixation which results from authors fixing a text passage by overwriting it (e.g. a pencilled passage fixed with ink).
Clarification a word is badly written and the author rewrites it to clarify. An example of that can be see at , where the first example, where we have two lost chars overwritten by 'er', then overwritten again, could be encoded as follows: Bæg
er erklang

*Alternatives when an author proposes several alternative readings for a segment without deciding which is the best. For those cases the TEI already offers a system (alt/) can be adapted. An example of that can be found in Vetter and McDonald 2003,
Lara Vetter and Jarom McDonald Witnessing Dickinson's Witnesses Literary Linguistic Computing 18 2 151-165 2003
where in the poem The inundation of the Spring by Emily Dickinson we found, amongst other, that the word estranged can be alternated with alarmed (written in-line, aster estranged) and submerged written at the bottom of the page; as estranged is underlined, the editors assume that this is the selected alternative (see pp. 155-162). Such case can be encoded as follows:
+ estranged - + alarmed
+ submerged -

Meta-marks (ge:metaMark): marginal notes and other additions to the text should be differentiated from meta-marks commanding an alteration (e.g. “move this passage over there”) or the date of the beginning of a manuscript or a revision, which represent a sort of processing instruction in the document. The element carries a function attribute which specify which is the function of the meta-mark and a target attribute which points to the element which the function refers. An example can be seen in the Emily Dickinson poem just shown, where the + sign marks that the word that follows is or has alternatives, so the example above could be re-encoded as follows:
+ estranged - + alarmed
+ submerged - Other examples of ge:metaMark can be represented by proofs' markup, like the ones that can be seen in several pages of Walt Whitman (see, for instance: ).

div.head: Deletions
div.p: Beside “normal” deletions (see for instance the TEI definition for del: “contains a letter, word, or passage deleted, marked as deleted, or otherwise indicated as superfluous or spurious in the copy text by an author, scribe, annotator, or corrector.”), we have outlined some other special kinds of deletion:

list.item:
Marked as used passages that happen to be struck through, where the strike marks the passage as used/copied at another location/another manuscript. In this case the author does not intend to suppress the content, but only to mark that it has been transferred or reused. We have created the ge:used element for this purpose. As the portions that are marked as used are normally full pages or large portions of pages, ge:used can contains zones or can be used within them. See an example of this in Walt Whitman ()
The Poet
I think His sight is the [...]
Overwriting is a particular case of a deletion, unless it is a case of repetition (repetion) or a false start (see below).

div.head: Transpositions
div.p: By transposition we mean words or blocks that are moved by the author to a different position using arrows, asterisks or numbers. A possible approach (used, for instance in HNML) would be to encode this as a substitution (i.e. to consider the segment previous to the transposition as deleted, and substituted by the one after the transposition) but this will not work for transposition of blocks.

list.item:
A new encoding should be envisaged: [hilde]
First: make the segment to be transposed addressable, either via an identifiable empty element (ge:trSpan/) or via a “cross-cutting” seg or similar.
Secondly: markup meta-marks which might be in the text (e.g. a super linear “add is here” or numbers “3 2 4 1” or asterisks), with an element ge:metaMark.
Relate the functional mark to the identified passages, either by referring to the passage added via attributes or implicitly because the ge:metaMark is contained in an add or del, as in the following example:

egXML.line:
This animal bird is a species found in dense
vegetation such as
5-6 eggs are laid in a nest in a low tree.

div.p: The re-alignment of the transposed blocks or segments can be supplied via a stand-off mechanism, to be used, for instance, within the teiHeader:

div.head: *Substitution
div.p:
The current TEI encoding considers a substitution as a combination of deletion/addition. Nevertheless there are cases in which a substitution includes more material. The current subst might therefore need a revision to allow more loose substitution like the following: [Justin]
indisputably & evidently become muchconsiderably worse

div.head: *Instant corrections and *false starts
div.p: Distinguishing instant correction from other kinds of alteration is important when establishing the timing of a specific revisions and in the whole genetic process. The information might be supplied as a specific attribute of add/, del/, subst etc., called *timing (or *instant or similar).

A specific subset of instant correction is represented by false starts, which are parts of a word that are overwritten by another (or struck through), meaning that the author started to write a word, then changed his/her mind and overwrote all or part of what was already written to fit the new word. This is an open problem: how to encode the partial word? Which is the scope of the correction? just the parts of the word that have been altered or all of it, even if this was not actually written? If it is possible to understand the word partially written, how should it be encoded? Will supplied a good candidate for that? [http://www.whitmanarchive.org/resources/sleepers/uva.00256.001.jpg]

Probably, in this latter case a new element should be added, called, perhaps ge:fStart, provided by a scope (part|full) and method (overwrite|stroked et simil.) attribute.EP: I think we should suggest a method attribute for tei:del as well, more specific than rend.

div.head: Undoing alterations
div.p: In some case authors undo alterations, e.g. a struck through passage may be restored via a dotted underlining, or the underlining of a passage may be deleted by a wavy line.

An element restore already exists in TEI for undoing a deletion, but we need a more general approach, for instance to delete underlining or transposition. We have introduced an element ge:undo for that purpose provided with at attribute target pointing at the element to be undone:
underline
[Leopardi]

Normally the element ge:undo would contain the element to be undone, except in the case of partial undoing as in the following example:
is nomadic

div.head: Grouping Revisions
div.p:
In some cases revisions can be attributed to a single campaign of revision (or text-stage), meaning we can say that a set of alterations (deletion, addition, substitution, transposition, etc.) are interrelated (i.e. one is a consequence of the other, they happened at the same time, etc.). To document this we need:
A system to attribute an alteration or any other phenomena occurring at document level to a particular revision campaign/text-stage
A way to describe a revision campaign/text-stage

For the former purpose ('attribute an alteration to a revision campaign') we have introduced a global attribute rev that points to an xml:id attribute within an element describing a specific text-stage; the element provided for that purpose is ge:revDesc which can occur within the teiHeader and groups the editorial reasons for stating that some alteration belong to a text-stage. Element ge:revDesc contains a sequence of ge:revNote, each of them describing a single text-stage. Typically, a ge:revNote will contain several references to ge:edJust elements (see below) and to other annotations contained within the teiHeader.

In many cases it is necessary to scope a portion of text in which one or more alteration occurs, in order to give the necessary context for any editorial discussion. For that purpose we have introduced an element ge:revision, which occurs within a ge:line or a p or any block and phrasal level elements. As the element is likely to overlap with other hierarchies (in particular it is very likely to overlap with ge:line in case the editor has chosen to encode the document level), we also provide a ge:revSpan/ empty element.

div.head: *Genetic Grouping
div.p: Alterations, revisions and other compositional phenomena may need to be grouped at dossier level: it might in fact occur that authors correct two versions at a time,Manzoni, for instance, used to modify an old draft to see how a new variant fitted with the context before copying it into a new draft.or we might need to express that two or more documents are related in other ways; for instance, one can be the sequel of the other, they might have been drafted at the same time, or one might contain some other kind of analogy, like a newspaper article that inspired some kind of reflection contained in a given work.

Such groupings can be encoded within a gi:geneticGrp element.EP: Sorry, but I don't like the name ge:textGroup, it is not clear enough. I appreciate we need a generic name, but we are not grouping texts, we are grouping: a) revisions; b) blocks (for instance when we want reorder chapters, as for Fotis' Kafka example; c) ???. I think ge:geneticGrp is clearer. As the element ge:geneticGrp can be used more generally for any kind of genetic grouping, a type attribute is also provided. ge:geneticGrp contains a sequence of ge:geneticNote whose targets attribute can refer to several ge:revNote of specific documents or to other annotations and editorial statements.

div.head: Genetic Relations
div.p: By genetic relations we mean the possibility of ordering different text-stages contained within a single document, or more probably, across different document into an ideal line of development, going, for instance from a version A to a version B (that can be represented by a different document or by an editorially reconstructed text-stage), to a version C, etc.
To do so, we have introduced the concepts of steps and paths for which we took inspiration from HNML.

div.head: Steps and Paths
div.p: A step connects two versions (represented by two documents or by two reconstructed text-stages within the same document), while a path connects two or more steps.

list.item:
ge:step embeds a relation attribute which points to description of a specific type of relation as defined by ge:geneticRel element (see); an attribute cert signifies the degree of certainty associated with the interpretation. Each ge:step element contains:EP: we need to clarify well the difference between a ge:step and a ge:geneticGrp, I am still not clear if we need both or only one (ge:geneticGrp, that is).
ge:stepNote: an editorial declaration which describes the arguments to assess such a step.
ge:stepLink targets=""/: a pointer to the two textual versions that compose a step.
ge:stepAlteration EP: guys I forgot why we need this!

ge:path in the same way as ge:step,embeds a relation attribute which points to description of a specific type of relation as defined by ge:geneticRel element (see); an attribute cert signifies the degree of certainty associated with the interpretation. A ge:path contains:
ge:pathNote: an editorial declaration which presents the arguments for the assessment of such a path.
ge:pathLink targets="": a pointer to the ge:step that compose the path.
ge:pathAlt: in some cases path can include alternative routes, for instance when a specific connection is uncertain, or when two or more (authorial) copies are derived from a specific witness. In this case the ge:pathAlt will include two or more ge:path elements and a gi:pathNote explaining the reasons for the bifurcation.

div.head: *Relationships
div.p: The type of connections existing between two or more textual variants (a step) or two or more steps (a path) need to be declared and described in order to be used. We have therefore introduced the element ge:geneticRel to be used within the profileDesc. A relation is defined in two ways: by a label (within a label) and via attributes defining different properties, such as:

list.item: *transitivity: the relation is transferable to all components of the group

*symmetry: the relation between A and B is equal to the relation there is between B and AEP: In how much depth shall we define a relationship? How many characteristics should we include? Can relationships be defined within the TEI or, for instance, by advising the use of other graph-oriented markup languages like RDF/XML?

div.p:
Examples of relations are:
Time one document or textual version follows or precede another
Evolutionary one document or textual version represent the evolution or the development of another
Thematic two or more documents concern the same topic
Conceptual two or more documents are connected in some logical way

div.head: *Collation and Critical Apparatus
div.p: As previously discussed (see), the moment at which the author decides to stop editing a draft and moves to another draft is arbitrary. Therefore alterations within a given document and alterations which result from the collation of different drafts of the same text are more conceptually connected than readings characterising different witnesses as a result of a scribal copy.

For instance, if we have two draft documents of the same text, A and B, if a deletion occurs within A or B we would probably mark it with a del element. On the other hand, if when comparing A and B, we see a passage has been suppressed, we would also probably mark it as such. Whether we need another set of editorial elements or we should use the same set that are used for transcription is still an open problem.

We can imagine at least two different scenarios:
Only one document has been entirely transcribed (perhaps the first or the last version), while the others are only reconstructable via collation, which can be stored within the same document or in a separate one.
All documents composing a dossier have been transcribed and the collation is stored in a separate document

div.head: One document is transcribed
div.p:
If, beside the base-text which is fully transcribed, all extant witnesses have to be reconstructed via collation, it is mandatory to be able to distinguish alterations that happen within them and between witnesses. For instance, using the existing tag set we could possibly encode as follows:
here is a passage in A

Nevertheless, this might force the intended usage of del and might imply that there is a deletion on B, which is not the case. This might be solved perhaps using the type attribute or another attribute or creating a new element (say ge:interDel) for deletions implied by collation, reserving del for deletions that happen at the document level.

div.head: All documents are transcribed
div.p: In this case we can assume that all alterations occurring at document level are already encoded within each transcription, therefore the collation will only need to point to passages within the separate files and classify the types of readings resulting from the collation:
The example encoding implies that attributes from and to are added to the rdg element.

div.head: Chronology, Date and Time
div.p: We want to express chronology as absolute and relative measures. Absolute time is the unambiguous reference to a calendar and time schema, while relative timing expresses events as happening before and/or after other events. Relative time can also be expressed by the relation to the (known or unknown) creation of another document or text. Dating can be justified by prose and/or by reference to a characteristic of a manuscript (e.g. hand, ink, etc.). The outlining of a chronology for a document or dossier can then be used as an argument to determine the existence of a text-stage.
We might be able to express absolute time by adapting existing element/attributes (timeline/ is a likely candidate), but more probably we need to create another element.LB: why?
For absolute timing we envisage two cases that can occur separately or in combination:

list.item: The dating of a witness (a manuscript part of a dossier) or of a zone may not be directly documented within its content, i.e. it can be deduced from external facts and documents. The editorial date attribution should be included in the teiHeader.

Dates can be found in the document added by the author as a kind of metadata (for instance the date of the beginning/ending of writing on a specific document, or the date of a revision campaign); those should be encoded without necessarily adding them in the teiHeader (they can be considered a type of meta-mark: see below)LB They might not always be true too; or at least, you might want to indicate who's responsible for the dating

div.p: We might express relative time as predecessor/successor-relationships

list.item: It might be a direct relationship: next, previous, sync.
It might be a “sorting” relationship: before, after.

Temporal relative relationships may also be expressed via a numbering scheme (0, 1, 2, …) within a *relTime ('relative time') attribute. In this case we assume a default timeline (the time of writing and of the instant corrections) which is represented by 0, and successive revision-times (1, 2, etc.)

div.p: Information about absolute or relative time can be given on all levels of a text or document.

div.head: Documenting Editorial Decisions
div.p: As genetic editions and genetic editing are essentially interpretative, documenting editorial decisions has a fundamental role.

Different forms of documentation have been discussed before in several previous sections:
ge:revNote: documents the constitution of a text-stage (see)
ge:geneticNote: documents the constitution of a genetic group (see)
ge:stepNote: documents the assessment of a connection between to text-stages (a step, see)
ge:pathNote: discusses the arguments for the creation of a connection between two or more steps (see) All these elements carry a cert attribute to declare the level of certainty; all of them shoulduse xml:id to be pointed at from many places in the text.LB: They should also perhaps always have a @resp attribute

But annotations can also occur in-line (i.e. close to a textual fragment they relate to) and for that reasons we created the ge:edJust global element. This should always be used with an xml:id attribute as the other types of annotations seen above are very likely to refer to specific points in the text within a more complex argument n. The target attribute points to the element to be annotated, while the locus attribute points to the concept to be justified. LB: ?????
The diary entry is dated. The entry precedes the other text on the witness by 22 years, as the ink analysis shows.

div.head: ODD
div.p: TEI Extension for Genetic Editions preliminary version

classSpec.desc: Contains elements that can be spanned across hierarchies.

remarks.p: When spanTo is used, the element must be empty.

elementSpec.desc: Document-centric container of a transcription of a primary source, containing topographical information as well as a transcriptions

attDef.desc: A reference to an arbitrary object that describes the placement and extent of the zone (such as an SVG element in an external file). The use of this attribute is exclusive of giving x/y-coordinates directly.

(surface orientation) The orientation that the surface has taken to enable the content (writing, images) in that zone, with respect to the normal orientation of the surface as assumed by the dimensions given in the msDesc section or by the coordinates of the surface itself. The orientation is expressed in arc degrees. The rotation is clockwise.

elementSpec.desc: Contains the transcription of a topographic line in the source document
(editorial justification) An editorial justification of any part of the edited text.

attDef.desc: Points to the element to be justified.
The location of the content to be justified.

elementSpec.desc: (revision description) A description of the various revisions that occurred in the text genesis.
Describes a revision in the text genesis.

Groups contained changes in the document to one revision. Changes are those indicated by add, del and other elements of model.pPart.transcriptional, as well as the undo, repetition and transposition elements.The rev attribute points to a description of the revision.
(meta mark) A textual or graphical element in a manuscript that is functional but not part of the text. Could transform the text, like a strikethrough, or provide meta-information, like a date.

attDef.desc: Describe to the function (e.g. add, delete, alternate) of the mark.
Points to the element(s) to which the function of the meta-mark refers. Pointers are separated by a white space

elementSpec.desc: In many cases, authors mark portions of text as having been used, usually meaning the text has been transcribed to a fair copy. The mark is often a strikethrough, but can be any author-specific mark.
Marks up an action represented by an element to be undone.

attDef.desc: The element representing the action to be undone.

elementSpec.desc: A clarification of already written text.
Describes a textual transposition. Contains a list of pointers that specifies the new order of the text fragments.

Groups contained changes in the document to one revision. Changes are those indicated by add, del and other elements of model.pPart.transcriptional, as well as the undo, repetition and transposition elements.The rev attribute points to a description of the revision.
(transposition) A part of the text that has been moved to a different location.

attDef.desc: A link to the element or passage represented by the node.
